content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure, honestly. My wife wanted me to come here, and I guess things have just been really overwhelming at home. I’m not even sure where to start.

It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed, and it’s brought you here today—sometimes taking that first step can feel like a lot in itself. What’s been going on at home that’s been overwhelming for you?

It's mostly my son. He's been acting out a lot, and it feels like nothing we do helps. It's putting a lot of stress on my wife and me—our marriage is really strained because of it. I also feel like I'm failing as a dad, and honestly, I don't even know how to help him anymore.

It must be really hard to feel like you're trying everything you can, yet still feeling stuck and unsure of how to support your son. It sounds like this situation is not only affecting him but also putting a lot of weight on your shoulders and your relationship with your wife. What has this been like for you?

It’s exhausting—I feel like I can't catch a break. I’m constantly worrying about my son, trying to help him without knowing how, and it’s taking a toll on everything else in my life. I can't focus at work, I don’t enjoy anything anymore, and my wife and I keep arguing about what to do. I just feel like I’m failing my whole family.

It sounds like you're carrying so much right now—trying to support your son, manage the stress in your marriage, and still handle everything else in your life. It seems like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself to make things better for everyone, and it's left you feeling drained and like you’re falling short. How do you see things improving, if they could?

Honestly, I don’t know. I want things to go back to how they were—when my son was happy, my wife and I were on the same page, and I wasn’t so overwhelmed all the time. But I don’t even know where to start. It just feels like too much.

It sounds like you really value the connection and happiness you had with your son and wife, and you're longing to get back to that place. At the same time, not knowing where to begin might feel paralyzing, especially when you’re facing so much at once. What do you think has been the hardest part for you about figuring out where to start?

Honestly, it’s the not knowing—just feeling like no matter what I do, it won’t be enough or it’ll make things worse. My son keeps struggling, my wife and I can’t agree on what to do, and I feel like I’m just stuck in the middle. It feels like everything’s on me, and I don’t even know if I can handle it.

It’s incredibly tough to feel like the weight of everything is resting on your shoulders, especially when you’re uncertain about the right path forward. You care so much about your family and want to support them, but it sounds like the constant pressure and uncertainty are leaving you feeling stuck and maybe even questioning your ability to manage. What would it mean for you to feel less alone in this?

It would mean a lot. I think I feel like I have to fix everything on my own, but I don’t know how. If I felt like someone really understood this and could help, maybe I’d feel less trapped. But I’m not great at asking for help—it’s hard to even be here.

It’s really brave of you to show up here and share all of this—it’s not easy to talk about these struggles, especially when you're used to feeling like you have to shoulder everything alone. It sounds like you're acknowledging how much you could benefit from support, even though reaching out feels tough. What might make it a little easier to take that step toward finding the help you need?

I don’t know—maybe if I knew it would actually help me figure things out. Right now, I feel like all I’d be doing is admitting how much I’m failing. But I guess... if it could help me help my family, maybe it’d be worth trying. I just don’t know where to even begin.

It sounds like there’s a lot of self-criticism mixed in with your concern for your family, but it also seems like deep down, you're open to the idea of trying—even if it feels difficult right now—because you care so much about your wife and son. Taking any step, however small, could be a powerful way to start. What do you think might be one simple way to begin exploring support for yourself in this?

Maybe talking to someone who works with families or kids who have behavioral challenges could be a start. I don’t know, though, part of me just hesitates because I’m not even sure what the "right help" looks like. I don’t want to waste time on something that won’t actually fix anything.

It’s understandable to feel hesitant when everything already feels overwhelming—you want to be sure that the time and energy you put in will really make a difference for your family. The idea of talking to someone who specializes in these challenges sounds like a meaningful step forward. What would make you feel more confident about giving it a try?

I guess if I knew they could really help, or if they’d give us some clear steps to take, that’d make me feel like it’s worth it. I just don’t want to get my hopes up and end up in the same spot. But I’ll admit, things can’t keep going like this, so maybe it’s worth seeing what they might have to say.

It sounds like you're in a place where you're balancing hope with caution. Wanting things to improve but not wanting to risk being let down is such a natural response given everything you've been through. At the same time, you're recognizing that exploring this support might be a way forward because staying where things are isn’t working. How would it feel to take things one step at a time and just start by reaching out to someone who works with families? Would that feel manageable?

I think that could feel manageable. If I can find someone who knows how to deal with situations like mine, I guess I can give it a try. I’m still skeptical, but I know I can’t do this alone anymore, and maybe they’ll have some advice I haven’t thought of. I think I’m okay to end the conversation for now—thank you for talking this through with me.
